A wise man once said said "all that is necessary for the triumph of evil is that good men do nothing" "In your heart you know he is right" The Frogg

And why quote a "wise man" if you don't know who he is or to what he was referring?

Topic.Title: Looks like some people in Mexico understand that guns are not just for hunting

Message.Msg: ... “…civilians have taken up arms in two towns in southwestern Mexico state and are arresting people of suspected crimes…” Ah, yes, another Tea Party nutball who believes in taking the law into his own hands and the mob mentality of wild-west vigilantism. “Suspected” crimes? Who are you to determine what a “suspected crime” is, much less apprehending, convicting and executing them on your own frivolous whim. You wack jobs who call the President of the United States Adolph Hitler should be running around with automatic weapons and a political philosophy of fear, intolerance and supremacy ala George Zimmerman…I don’t think so, junior. “Okay, boys, round up jon, Alex Jones and the rest of the impotent little dweebs and grab the sheets and ropes…the frog posse rides at midnight!!! Yippie, Hooo-boy!!!!” In my heart, I know you are as ignorant as jon…just another frightened little weenie being used by the gun lobby. When will you hilljacks realize that The NRA doesn’t care a rat’s a#s about you…they represent the arms industry, and you fools buy into it. “Mommie,mommie, they’re coming after our guns…what will I do then? I’m powerless without my male extension.” Well, if you like it so much, you COULD move to that town in southwestern Mexico. Adios, dipstick.

How ironic for you to mention anger. Anger – the fuel of mob rule, vigilantism and lynchings…what you preach is the epitome of anger. How about some answers for a change instead of frog philosophy. You, likewise, have a fine day. Watch out for the walleye and bass lurking for lunch, frogman.

Topic.Title: Looks like some people in Mexico understand that guns are not just for hunting

Message.Msg: The Federalist Papers had nothing to do with the supreme court, you nitwit. The Federalist Papers were a series of writings by a group of American thinkers that advocated a strong centralized federal govenment. Thomas Jefferson and his followers were opposed to a strong federal govenment and advocated states rights. In fact the bill of rights ( the first 10 amendments is the answer to the Federalist Papers ) were added to restrict the rights of the federal govenment. The Constitution could not be approved until the bill of rights were added, naming what rights were reserved for the people. I see Frogg didn't make it through the 7th grade. Too bad.

Message.Title: second amendment
Message.Msg: A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed. What do you guys think the words " a well regulated Militia" means? If the founding fathers had ment only "the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed.", that is what the amendment would say. However, it says "A well regulated Militia." How can even some of you take that to mean that a Litano gang member has the right to run around with an AK-15 shooting folks or others walking around with magazine clips shooting kids in school. Are those folks part of a well regulated Militia? And don't even mention the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court has ,at various times, ruled that slavery was allowed in the Constitution, that harbering a slave was illegal, that seperate but equal was equal, that women do not have the right to vote, that American Indians do not have the right to vote, that Japanese-American Citizens can be arrested without a trial and held indefinately, that Japanese-American Citizen's property can be confiscated without proper compensation, that habius corps can be suspended whenever the poweres that be deem it necessary, etc, etc.

Topic.Title: second amendment

Message.Msg: By golly you are right. We need to form State Militias right away so we can effectively defend ourselves when they come for our guns. California's State Guard has been Nationalized so we no longer have a State Militia. Our San Bernardino County Sheriff says he will arrest anyone attempting to confiscate guns but I am not sure he is capable of doing so. We need a State Militia that is well trained and equipped to defend against those who would try to confiscate guns.

Message.Title: U.S. Failure
Message.Msg: Ok. First, the Fed says that they may not have enough to pay my Social Security in my Senior years, which are upon me now. I payed into this for 43 years, and thought we had an agreemenrt. I guess not ironclad. Then they say that Medicare will be compromised because too many undeserving, non- paying folks are now attached to it. That will affect me negatively very late in the game. I would have taken better care of myself if I had known this. Now they say that my U. S. Savings Bonds, which I have been buying for 45 years, are in danger of being defaulted upon. I thought that we had a Bond, Treasury Department. I am keeping up my end. Why would you even consider not paying me off for these Bonds? What a bunch of losers. And finally, they say that my 401K Money Market funds, which are uninsured, could be attached ( Federal Employees are in that boat). If you need to borow some money from me, you must suck badly. What exactly do I have left? All agreements that I made have been, or are under consideration for reneging upon.. As far as I am concerned, the U.S. Govt can kiss my butt. I don't have any respect for any entity which backs out on its committmernts, and changes the rules on somebody as old as me.

Topic.Title: Looks like some people in Mexico understand that guns are not just for hunting

Message.Msg: Mexico (like much of Chicago) is being run by two major drug cartels (the Zetas and the Sinaloa). To date neither the former government of Filipe Calderon nor the current government of Pena Nieto have been able to alter the control held by these two organizations. So my point was to give praise to a few good people in southwestern Mexico who had the nerve to take back (if only for a moment) their own destinies. If some how you find this offensive, then I pity you and people like you. "In your heart you know he is right" The Frogg

Topic.Title: Looks like some people in Mexico understand that guns are not just for hunting

Message.Msg: One of the things the Mexican government has asked the US government to do is stop the sale of assault rifles which are bought here and smuggled into Mexico. You are upset that a drug cartel has the firepower to take on the government and you think the solution to that is armed bands of civilians roaming the streets "arresting" people. Do you know what sensible people call that? They call it a failed state. A great plan. It goes well with your bankrupt the government plan. Let's hope we don't end up like Mexico. Let's hope we stop feeding drug cartels assault rifles.

Topic.Title: Looks like some people in Mexico understand that guns are not just for hunting

Message.Msg: The answer is yes. It has always been yes. We have three branches of government with overlapping powers. These form a series of checks and balances. The role of the executive branch is to faithfully execute the laws. The executive branch *always* has the authority to enforce or not enforce a law. They *always* have the authority to prioritize the laws they execute Whether it is the local police chief choosing to priortize property crimes over traffic infractions or the Attorney general choosing to prioritize gun smuggling over immigration. "Faithfully" is a subjective term--one to be interpreted by the voters. You may not like what they choose to prioritize or execute. In that case, vote. But prioritizing and selectively enforcing the law is precisely what the executive branch is supposed to do. When Bush II decided to ignore Civil Rights laws I didn't like it. But I knew it was in his Constitutionally granted authority to do so.
